segments.text: But I think what we need in a port such as this is a mix between good, substantial, solid citizen local types, people who are from this area.
We want them, but a good mix also of people from outside the area.
Most of whom will come in and live two or three years and then want to transfer back where they came from.
I don't know if that would do it.
We try to, because drugs is so corrupt and because there's so much money involved, and because we know that an officer who is well known in the community might be approached
We try to take every precaution.
We try to set up an atmosphere here in the court that won't allow any officer to ever do anything illegal because there's always somebody who might see him do it.
In other words, we're all watching each other.
It's hard to work under those conditions.
Whenever somebody goes wrong, it at least is in part because there's an atmosphere that he worked in that allowed it to happen.
I'm convinced that, let me give you an example of this sort of thing.
We had an officer.
When I first came here, he was arrested for molesting a teenage girl out here.
She was crossing the border and he allegedly molested her and she complained.
She was 14 years old.
She complained to her mother and ultimately they went to the police and they charged him.
He was convicted.
And we got this officer.
He transferred in from US Immigration Service.
We get a lot of, or have in the past, had a lot of bilateral transfers from my agency.
It's supposed, it should be a good way of recruiting people.
But anyway, this guy got arrested and ultimately went to court and was convicted.
And I asked around, because I was new here,
And I went over to immigration and in conversation would bring him up and ask, what do you think about so-and-so?
And invariably they'd say, oh, we knew this guy was, I'm not surprised that this guy had a long history of this kind of stuff.
I said, what are you talking about?
And they'd say, well, he was in the border patrol and he almost got fired for getting involved with some young girl
When he was here as a customs, when he was in immigration, they were getting ready to fire him.
And then new people picked him up.
And he wasn't here 18 months before he got arrested.
And he'd been in five or six years.
And he had this history all through it.
And people knew?
Yeah.
And in other words, they allowed this sort of thing to happen.
And he supposedly was dating, he's a 30-year-old man, he was supposedly dating one of our Explorer Scouts, a 16 or 17-year-old high school girl out here, and everybody knew it.
I didn't know it.
I would have put a stop to it.
But what I'm saying is that he had this reputation, and nobody seemed to give a damn that he was doing this.

In fact, when the Immigration Service, they were going to fire him for this same sort of thing, and he applies for a job, probably to save himself, and it's almost like in the old days, World War II days, and just after when a juvenile offender was taken before the judge and he was given this choice to either go to jail or go in the Army.
And it seems like what we were getting with, they were telling them either go to jail or go to customs.
And I went to Internal Affairs when I heard this.
I said, what the hell is going on?
Everybody tells me that they knew this guy was doing these sorts of things.
How did we get him?
Didn't you interview people?
Didn't you do a background check?
And they said, yes, we did.
Well, they actually did a full field.
investigation on this guy's background.
I said, didn't you go to the immigration service and ask questions?
They said, yeah.
I said, well, how did we get this guy?
He said, well, we didn't ask the right questions.
And I said, didn't they, and nobody volunteered that this guy was?
He said, no, they didn't volunteer because they wanted to get rid of him.
And this is a, you know, it's a
It's kind of a bizarre example, but we permit this to happen.
These two guys, one of whom got recently convicted on the two bribery counts, he was always flashing money out here.
I found out after the fact.
He was always bragging about his conquests with the girls.
He was acting like a two-bit hustler out here.
And everybody was just, they sort of were entertained by him.
And by listening to him brag, watching him flash his big bankrolls of money, he had over $1,000 in cash when he was arrested.
He had $16,000 in cash hidden away in his house.
You know what I mean?
Yeah.
That's what we're trying to do as far as integrity.
We're trying to not allow it to happen by making an atmosphere that makes it impossible for somebody to do this.
And the only way we can do that is everybody has to watch everybody else.
I'm in business school at A&M.
And they're teaching us right now about internal control.
And they're saying no one likes it until there's a problem.
And everyone loves it because at least there is a witness that can say .. We have dozens of internal controls.
Every aspect of customs operation.
We have somebody who's responsible to take a look at this particular type of transaction.
and to take a look at the control and make sure it's working.
Unfortunately, when you have to do it on a quarterly or bimonthly or monthly or by every pay period basis, it becomes so routine that people begin to just sign your name, send the paper in,
In other words, they go through the motions.
So we're also trying to make sure that when an officer is responsible for a specific control, that he really does what he's supposed to do.
He goes and he talks to people involved in that particular activity.
He says, do you do this?
Or how do you handle a certain, how do you get the cash from this location
over there if you're safe.
And the guy says, well, I fill out such and such a form.
I put it in this bag.
I lock it.
I take it over and someone signs for it.
I say, okay, you show me how you do it instead of just taking his word for it.
So we're working on that.
We're working on integrity.
We have musters twice a week where the officers on the day shift meet
for an hour or a half hour.
And we talk about integrity all the time.
I send electronic mail messages frequently about integrity.
We constantly reinforce, reinforce the need not only to be of the highest standards themselves, but to insist that their fellow officers also do
And the first suspicion, we had a response to let us know so we didn't do something wrong.
Because when someone gets arrested, as has happened here, it hurts us all for a long time.
We had officers who were called up by friends and acquaintances when those two guys were arrested, asking
saying such things, because I hope you're not involved and not in the building at the time.
I'm not really aware of what it hurts when people call me out.
In another issue of Newsweek, it was reported that the United States gave Mexico $140 million in drug enforcement aid.
Was that money productive, or could it have been better spent elsewhere, here in the States, on education?
Well, I think it probably is worth the effort.
I don't know whether it was cost productive, cost effective or not.
I look at the drug war as an international thing.
It's not an American problem.
It's not a Mexican problem.
It has to be hit from every angle.
And I think that it's proper for us to be spending money in Mexico.
Unfortunately, we have tried in the past for years to get Mexican officials to cooperate with us on drug trafficking.
And for years, it hasn't worked.
We've had several operations down here on the border that when we tried to work with the Mexicans, we gave them money, radios, weapons, in exchange for intelligence.
And we never, they took the,
equipment and the money that never gave us anything back.
And so that program sort of foundered for obvious reasons.
But I've got to say that it appears that like the Mexican authorities are really trying to do, they're really doing their best, they're trying very hard
to contain drugs, to make seizures, to stop the trafficking through their country.
I don't know why this is.
I think it's international pressure.
No country wants to be known as the drug capital of the world.
There are three South American countries in Vietnam.
Mexico, as far as the United States is concerned, certainly has what it takes as being the number one traffic in the country as far as I'm concerned.
Virtually everything, as we said before, most everything comes through Mexico, if not the United States.
But it looks like they're really trying to do something about it.
It could be because
they perceive themselves as having a drug problem of their own.
This gets their attention.
This is kind of off the subject, but I'll give you an idea of where my philosophy comes from.
I used to work overseas in customs.
And back in 1973, I went to Thailand
work with a group of American and Thai customs and drug officials trying to develop contacts and trying to get them to cooperate.
And at that time, it was Southeast Asian countries, as Thailand, that were major trafficking and producing countries for heroin from the United States.
Thailand at that time was what Mexico is now.
Everything that came to the United States seemed to come through Thailand.
And so we were over there working with them, trying to give them money, equipment, and everything else, trying to get them to stop the flow.
And I had a fairly high-level official over there
told me that, first of all, they resented us being there at that time and trying to tell them how to run their country.
And they were convinced and didn't mind saying that this was not a Thai problem.
Drugs was an American problem.
Americans would, it was an American demand.
It was even Americans, they claimed, who were trafficking through Thailand.
At that time, they were accusing the American military, because we still had military people there, bringing it through and out.
And they were very hostile toward our efforts, uncooperative, and even arrogant.
They said, you're proud.
Don't bother us with this.
I went back, though.
Two or three years had passed.
In fact, I think I went back again in 1979, six years later.
Some of the same people were in the same group.
This was a group of drug and, let's say, customs people from all over the world, going to Thailand and the United States.
And so it was like old home with it.
I knew a lot of these people on a personal basis.

And the very same person who six years previously had told me and others that this was an American problem and that you were off base coming to their country and telling them how to run their country, he addressed this whole group of drug people.
And the first thing he said was, we have a drug problem here in Thailand and we need your help.
He was turned around, and what he was saying was, now we need your help.
It is a Thai problem, he was saying.
And he was saying that they looked up one day, and they found they had 50,000 addicts in Bangkok.
Thais, not Americans, Thais.
And they probably have a heck of a lot more than that.

The only thing, and I think the same thing was true of France, of a lot of the Western European countries that we tried to get assistance from in the drug trafficking, they never perceived it as an international problem until they saw themselves as having a problem with addicts and traffickers in their own country.
I think the same thing might be happening in Mexico.
I think they perceive this now as being a Mexican problem
because the drugs aren't just coming through.
They're actually, some of them are winding up in the Mexicans.
I think the same thing is happening in Columbia.
The Columbians now are cracking down on the cartels are trying to in all the newspapers.
And I have a feeling that the reason why is they see themselves as having a drug problem in Columbia.
If there were no addicts in Columbia, then they probably would continue to just wade through the mud, considering it an American problem.
And now they see it as a Colombian problem.
And it may be too late.
I don't know.
But I think Mexico, in that sense, is really .
OK.
This is going in a completely different direction.
But how would you compare the Mexican border to the Canadian border?
Is there any basis for comparison in a completely different way?
About the only similarity is that they're both borders.
Canada, of course, is as much like the United States as you can get.
It's not like a foreign country.
There's a lot of free trade between the United States and Canada.
Reciprocal.
There are no drugs coming in to the United States through Canada.
We know of very little, if there is.
There's a lot of drugs.
Is there a problem with drugs coming through the United States through Canada?
I would say yes.
I've never read any of them.
I'd have to guess yes because the drugs have to come from somewhere.
They have a problem in Canada as well as the United States.
They probably come up through Mexico, through the United States, into Canada.
Now, putting the shoe on the other foot, I don't know if we're giving them the kind of assistance that they want or that we would expect Mexico to give us.
I hope we are.
I think we are.
There's been some talk of using the military or the National Guard to help control the borders.
What are your thoughts on that?
I think as a temporary situation, I think we're using National Guard right now to help us in a lot of these big border stations.
to help us inspect cargo.
Under the direction of custom inspectors, they go out on the cargo dock and help us watch and unload trucks so that we can do a good job inspecting it again.
As far as troops out in the field between the ports, if that's what you're referring to, I think yes.
by all means, let's do it.
I think politically it's a little dangerous.
The Mexicans and the Canadians vote, of course, but we're talking strictly about the southern border now.
They resent anything that would look like we were arming our borders, massing the troops, so to speak, at the borders.
It's an act of hostility in their eyes toward a country that we haven't been in war with since, well, since the Mexican-American War.
And it's been not an open border, but it's been an unarmed border for all those years.
And on the one hand,
I think there would be a lot of protest from the Mexicans in general.
On the other hand, a lot of them understand that we're doing what we have to do.
They use their own troops on the Mexican side for drug interdiction.
And they're doing a pretty good job, from what I understand.
And it seems logical to me that they would also approve us doing the same on this side of the border.
But I think anything that could help bring this thing under control, if we didn't try it, it couldn't hurt.
Now we're going to on to even a different subject.
Officer safety.
Is the perceived threat on officer safety a real threat on the border?
Yeah, it is.
Customs, as a law enforcement activity, is probably not as dangerous as a lot of other law enforcement activities.
It's not like being a policeman in a big city, a prime minister in a big city.
Most of what we do is routine.
Every once in a while, though,
um there is this element of danger we we we try to we treat pops or safety as every person needs to watch out for himself and every person also needs to watch out for those around them we're under
We work under the Treasury Department rules on law enforcement.
We are armed.
The only justification for an officer pulling, drawing a weapon is if he intends to shoot somebody.
It's the only justification.
You don't pull a gun to hold somebody, to cover somebody.
Well, we don't do it.
It's strictly self-defense and in defense of other innocent people.
We have taken certain measures.
We have installed security cameras.
Some of ours aren't operational yet, but all along the border, we're putting in TV cameras and monitors, bulletproof glass.
in a lot of our buildings.
We have bullet-resistant vests that the officers can wear if they want options, if they feel threatened, or if there's a lookout on an armed and dangerous situation.
We believe in the buddy system.
We don't send anybody out to inspect a truck
or an airplane at the airport by itself, people in pairs, supposedly one watching the other.
We just take every precaution to protect ourselves.
And does the recent ban on assault rifles have any significant impact on this?
I don't think it will, because I think there are already enough
in the hands of criminals, that they can do a lot of damage to us.
The other thing that a lot of the inspectors now are carrying semi-automatic pistols.
They're high powered.
Instead of the six shot revolver,
A lot of us are carrying in 12 to 15 shot 9mm semi-automatic pistons that will fire very rapidly.
A lot of bullets in a short period of time without having to reload it.
I don't know what kind of defense we could put up against
automatic weapons.
I don't know.
We don't have any automatic weapons.
I don't think the band can make a difference now.
Okay.
On just another little different tangent, the 1986 Immigration Act, where they gave amnesty to the illegal residents of over eight years, has that had any impact on protecting our borders?
No, I don't think so.
The immigration situation is different from the drug situation.
It's not to say that some of these people maybe won't carry small amounts in, or even large amounts.
We don't know.
But I think what the amnesty program has probably brought more and more people from Mexico, interior, and even more than that from Central America,
into this area, looking for ways to do that.
I don't think it affects customs, per se, that much.
Okay, and two final questions.
First of all, are we winning the war?
And if not, what would it take to win?
We're clearly not winning the war.
As I say, I've been involved in this war, so-called war, since the Nixon administration, and it's only gotten worse every year since 1973.
Every year is worse than the year before.
The only way to win the war, in my mind, is a multi-directional kind of an effort.
But the most important thing is we've got to stop the demand for it.
I don't know how to do that.
I don't know whether it means we have to arrest people who use it.
We certainly need education, prevention, treatment, decriminalization maybe.
I don't know.
I don't know what the answer is.
All I know is that there's always going to be an element in this society that appears to want to do the illegal drugs.
Maybe only because they're illegal.
They're always going to want to turn their friends on to it.
Everybody knows crack is dangerous.
But you've got a million kids who want to do it.
I don't know why.
You've got to get rid of the demand.
As long as there's a demand, there are going to be people who are going to figure out some way to get into this country.
If they can't get into this country, then they're going to find a way to manufacture something locally.
It's the demand that's the problem, because as long as there's a demand, there are going to be people who are going to make money from it.
Thank you very much, Mr. King.
I appreciate your time.
